Objectives

Description
and
Introduction
All lectures, except for the introductory one, will follow this structure:
Presentation (90 minutes)
Discussion about work done during the week (e.g., papers that have been read, assignment that has been carried out) (25 minutes)
Description of work to be done for the following week (5 minutes)
Evaluation will be done on the basis of: weekly work and participation in discussion (15%), Build an ontology  (55%) and research work (30%)
Send your hands-on to the following email
masterr09@delicias.dia.fi.upm.es
Ontology assignment

Some people have requested additional information about the ontology assignment that will be used to obtain the 55% of the final qualification. These are the details of this assignment: Each group will have to select a domain on which they can build a network of domain ontologies. They have to show how they can apply a methodological approach to build this network of ontologies, justifying adequately aspects like planning, requirement specifications, non-ontological resources reused, conceptualisation and evaluation. The network of ontologies should be of approximately 40-50 concepts and 10 properties. They have to implement them in OWL, using a mix of atomic, primitive and defined classes, and showing how they can exploit inferences. This will have to presented by the end of the semester.
Schedule and Material

Lectures will be held every Wednesday in lecture room 3103, from 11:00 to 13:00.
14/10/2009. Introduction (Asun)
Recomended reading: Tim Bernes Lee articles
Slides: [
Intro Sweb
]
Assignment: Choose between one of them.
Read the article written by TBL in 1996 and 2002 and summarize his vision in three pages
Read the "Radar and Networks & Nova Spivack" vision published in 2007. Summarize it in three pages
What is the Future Internet and which one is the relationship with the semantic Web. Summarize it in three pages.
Deadline: 20/10/2009 9pm
21/10/2009. Theoretical Foundations of Ontologies  (Asun)
Recommended reading: Chapter 1 and 2 of the book "Ontological Engineering"
Slides: [
Foundations of ontologies
]
Assignment:Choose betwen one of them.
Read and comment the following paper that includes several definitions of ontologies: Guarino N, Giaretta P (1995) Ontologies and Knowledge Bases: Towards a Terminological Clarification. In: Mars N (ed) Towards Very Large Knowledge Bases: Knowledge Building and Knowledge Sharing (KBKS’95). University of Twente,Enschede, The Netherlands. IOS Press, Amsterdam, The Netherlands, pp 25–32
Search papers on the topic of Ontological Commitments.  Read, comment and compare at least the following two papers:
Gruber, T.; Olsen, G. An Ontology for Engineering Mathematics. Fourth International Conference on Principles of Knowledge Representation and Reasoning.  Ed by Doyle and Torasso. Morgan Kaufmann. 1994. Also as KSL-94-18.
Guarino, N.; Carrara, M.; Giaretta, P. Formalizing Ontological Commitments. 12th National Conference on Artificial Intelligence. AAAI-94. 1994. 560-567
Choose a domain and find  ontological and non ontological available resources consensuated by a community. Classify them in the continuous line identified by Lassila and McGuiness. Justify why they are important and how do you know that they represent consesuated knowledge.
Identify a set of criteria to be used to compare technologies used for searching ontologies. Classify existing technologies according to the criteria.
Deadline: 3/11/2009
Presentation: Students will be selected randomly to present their assigments

Recommended reading:

Recommended reading:
[1] Cuenca Grau B, Horrocks I, Kazakov Y, Sattler U. Just the Right Amount: Extracting Modules from Ontologies. WWW2007,
[2] Horridge M, Parsia B, Sattler U. Laconic and Precise Justifications in OWL. ISWC2008.
[3] Schlobach S, Cornet R. “Non-standard reasoning services for the debugging of description logic terminologies”. In Proceedings of the 18th International Joint Conference on Artificial Intelligence (IJCAI), Acapulco, Mexico: 355-362. (2003)

http://www.co-ode.org/resources/papers/ekaw2004.pdf
[5] Corcho O, Roussey C, Vilches-Blázquez LM and Pérez I. Pattern-based OWL Ontology Debugging Guidelines. Proceedings of the Workshop on Ontology Patterns (WOP 2009), collocated with the 8th International Semantic Web Conference (ISWC-2009), Washington D.C., USA, 25 October, 2009.

25/11/2009. Methodologies I (Asun)
The objective of this lecture is to show scenarios for the construction of ontologies, and provide methods and tools to create the ontology requirement specification, the search of potential resources to be reused, the selection of the ontology life cycle model and planning the ontology development.
Recommended reading:
NeOn Glossary of Activities
D5.4.1. NeOn Methodology for Building Contextualized Ontology Networks
[7]
Ontology requirement specification.
[8]
;
Planning and Scheduling:
Chapters 3 and 4
Slides:
[9]
NeOn Toolkit to be download:
Download
Assignment: The International Olympic Committee decides to rely on semantic technologies to manage information related to the Olympic Games. For this purpose, such a committee needs an ontology network able to model information about the sports (summer and winter), about countries and teams involved, about venues and dates, and about medals and winners. Each group should focus on winter or summer sports; and should select one particular sport to define it in more detail.
Write the ontology requirement specification document (ORSD) using the methodological guidelines and the provided material, and documenting in detail the decisions taken.
Use FreeMind Software for writting the competence questions
[10]
The template for writting the ORSD (ontology requirement specification document):
ORSD Template
Quick search for non-ontological resources in internet and ontologies using Watson that could be reused during the ontology development.
Schedule the ontology network development using the gOntt plugin included in the NeOn toolkit.
Deadline: 1/12/2009
Fill in the questionnaire
[11]
regarding the guideliness related with ontology requirement specification.
Do the same
[12]
about the gOntt plug-in.
2/12/2009. Methodologies II (Asun, Boris, Jorge)
The goal of this lecture is to present methods and tools for reusing and re-engineering non-ontological resources into ontologies and for mapping ontologies.
Recommended reading (Reusing and Re-engineering non-ontological resources):
D5.4.1. NeOn Methodology for Building Contextualized Ontology Networks
[13]
Chapter 6: Non-Ontological Resource Reuse and Re-engineering.
D2.2.2. Methods and Tools Supporting Re-engineering
[14]
Chapter 2: State of the Art.
Chapter 3: NeOn Method for Re-engineering Non-ontological Resources.
Chapter 4: Methods for Re-engineering Classification Schemes.
Chapter 5: Methods for Re-engineering Thesauri.
Recommended reading (Ontology Matching):
J.Euzenat "Tutorial on Ontology Matching" (at least the section titled "Matching problem").
[15]
Jorge Gracia and Eduardo Mena, "Web-based Measure of Semantic Relatedness", Proc. of 9th International Conference on Web Information Systems Engineering (WISE 2008), Auckland (New Zealand), Springer Verlag LNCS, volume 5175, pp. 136-150, September 2008.
[16]
Slides: 1.
A Method for Reusing and Re-engineering Non-Ontological Resources for Building Ontologies
Slides: 2.
Semantic Measures and Ontology Matching: an Overview and some Examples
Assignment:
We select a domain and provide to the students an ontology, a classification scheme and a thesaurus.
Student groups perform minor changes in the occupation ontology. They should add at least 3 new classes for the IT domain.
Student groups build the ontology using the PR-NOR software library from the selected thesaurus.
Student groups build the ontology using the PR-NOR software library from the selected classification scheme.
Student groups compare the generated ontologies against the occupation ontology.
Student groups fill in a questionnaire about the similarity between the occupation ontology and the two generated ones.
Details are available at:
Homework 5
Note about the software to be used:
Software Homework 5
Deadline: Friday 11/12/2009

The information of this class is available at
Eva Blomqvist class

Requirements and Services for Metadata Management. Missier P, Alper P, Corcho O, Dunlop I, Goble C. IEEE Internet Computing 11(5): 16-24
Toward a New Generation of Semantic Web Applications. d'Aquin M, Motta E, Sabou M, Angeletou S, Gridinoc L, Lopez V, Guidi D. IEEE Intelligent Systems, June 2008
Slides:
Slides
Assignment: Taking into account the domain ontologies generated in th previous assignments, select a set of Web pages, wikis, databases or any other resources and make ontology-based annotations about them, publishing them in a suitable form.
Deadline: 26/1/2010 9pm

The goal of this lecture is to present guideliness for reusing top level ontologies and building the conceptual model taking into account the developments done in previous activities.
